title: Kenya: Turning Kenya Into a 24-Hour Economy Will Boost Development
text:
Kenya: Street Kids Swoop Ahead of Obama Tour 
What this has done is that other businesses close to the supermarkets have also now embraced the 24-hour economy concept. It is now even more encouraging that the government is going out of its way to ensure that, in line with Vision 2030, Nairobi turns into the region's premier 24-hour economic hub. 
The benefits of a 24-hour economy are enormous and cannot be wished away for a country like Kenya that is on the path of attaining middle-income status. 
A 24-hour economy does not only help us deal with congestion witnessed during the day, but also helps in job creation. We know that jobs are one of our key needs in the country, and this concept can help us deal with it as more manpower is needed to handle the long hours. 
We know the greatest economic growth is driven by an increase in productivity, and a 24-hour economy ensures that more is produced thus reducing the cost of production. A fully operative 24-hour economy will enable us to increase productivity by allowing us to do more with the available space, manpower and technology. 
A 24-hour economy will also ensure growth of other amenities that are needed for its success such as water, electricity and transport infrastructure. 
President Uhuru Kenyatta's commitment to ensuring that Kenya and Kenyans grow economically is in no doubt. The President has personally been supervising the lighting up of Nairobi and installation of surveillance as part of the plan to encourage the 24-hour economy. 
A few months back, the President led the Cabinet in endorsing a work-plan to ensure Nairobi is well lit and has a conducive environment for late-night business. The President asked the National Treasury to allocate Sh953 million for lighting up Nairobi through Kenya Power. 
As a result, close to 15,000 new lanterns, public lighting masts and floodlights have been installed in Nairobi, and the city looks brighter and cleaner. 
We know that 4,255 lights had been installed in Nairobi CBD and the environs by last month. Of these, 1,954 lanterns have been improved in the city centre, Ngara and Murang'a Road. In Westlands, which has been one of the hubs of Nairobi nightlife, 332 lights have been installed. Information released by government shows that in other parts of Nairobi, 2,472 improved lanterns will be installed by August 30. 
What we are witnessing is a transformation of the capital that will make it easier to do business at night. Already, Nairobi is listed as one of the cities with the most vibrant nightlife in Africa - meaning that this can be extended to the other areas of the economy. 
We are ranked third among the world-fastest growing economies, and a 24-hour concept helps us even grow faster. Not everything must be done during the day. We can leave some issues and do them at night, and at the same time ease congestion that chokes city streets during the day. 
The government is doing a lot in ensuring that the cost of doing business comes down as well as putting in place an enabling environment. This is commendable and we must support the government's efforts by embracing these emerging concepts. 
One of the issues that has stalled turning Kenya into a 24-hour economy has been the cost of energy. It is commendable the Jubilee administration is working hard not only to increase connectivity but to also make energy affordable especially for large consumers such as industries. 
Reducing the cost of energy for manufacturers and industries will help bring the cost of living down as well as helping reduce over-reliance on imports. This will also increase the number of exports from the country and as a result increase foreign earnings. 
Towards this end, President Uhuru Kenyatta, last week, launched Kenya's single biggest energy investment in Marsabit county. The Sh72 billion Lake Turkana Wind Power project will boost Kenya's capacity by nearly 20 per cent, and add 310MW (310,000 kilowatts) of clean energy to the national grid, the company behind the venture has said. 
The wind farm is the single largest private sector investment on 40,000 acres (162sq km) in Loyangalani, and with 365 turbines. It is also the biggest turbine order ever done in the world, and the biggest wind power project in Africa. 
The Loyangalani project is very significant for Kenya, and with its huge transmission infrastructure likely to be used to connect future projects to the grid. It is an example of large-scale and privately funded infrastructural projects that are possible in Kenya, and will attract similar ventures to the country. 
The writer is a political and communications consultant. Kenya
